title: Greetings!
text:
A place where curiosity leads the way and muddy boots are just part of the journey.
This site is a growing collection of projects, research, tutoring resources, adventure photos, and the occasional feline cameo.

title: Meet Rebecca!
text:
Hi! I‚Äôm Rebecca ‚Äî an Environmental Studies major at the University of California, Santa Barbara (UCSB), student researcher, and mom of two incredible teenagers. I‚Äôve taken an unconventional path to college, but every step has shaped who I am today. I‚Äôm passionate about hands-on learning and finding meaningful ways to connect science with the world around us.


üõ§Ô∏è My Path
Before returning to school, I balanced work, family life, and five years serving in the Marine Corps Reserves. Community college rekindled my love for science and service. At Allan Hancock College, I worked as a tutor and mentor, helping other students as I grew in my own studies. Now at UCSB, I‚Äôm blending research, education, and community involvement to build a path that feels purposeful and rewarding.





Once Upon a Time.





Allan Hancock College.





√ó 






üåø Learning by Doing
Sometimes the best way to learn is by jumping in and experiencing it firsthand. Fieldwork brings my studies to life by connecting science with real environments and showing how those environments impact our world. I believe hands-on experience is one of the best ways to inspire students and anyone who‚Äôs still finding their place in science.




Harvesting lavender to distill into oil.





With Kayla Geronimo-Anctil on Santa Cruz Island Reserve.



You can explore my projects and photos pages to see what I‚Äôve been up to.



üë©‚Äçüëß‚Äçüë¶ Life & Inspiration
I‚Äôm a proud mom of two amazing teenagers who inspire me every day. When I‚Äôm not studying or working, I enjoy volunteering, spending time outdoors, and relaxing with my cats, Chester and Leo.




My Family.





Chester and Leo.



Curious about Chester and Leo? You can find more fluffiness here.



‚ù§Ô∏è Giving Back
Giving back has always been a priority for me. Whether mentoring, volunteering, or supporting community efforts behind the scenes, I believe showing up and contributing makes a difference. Over the years, I‚Äôve been involved with groups like Toys for Tots, local outreach, and She Raised Her Hand.




Toys for Tots Event (holding the unicorn).





Proclamation presented by the City of Santa Maria to She Raised Her Hand.



Please visit She Raised Her Hand for more information and upcoming events.
If you‚Äôd like to support seasonal giving efforts, donations can be made through Toys for Tots.

title: Projects
text:
This page highlights some of my work from classes and research.


School



üí° Service Light Personal Data



School: UCSB
Course: ENVS 193DS ‚Äì Data Science for Environmental Studies
Ongoing project that explores the relationship between lighting conditions and service calls using a self-collected dataset (n=108). Created a bar chart, summary table, and a blinking lightboard animation (gif). See visuals.
Tools Used:
RStudio (tidyverse, here, flextable, janitor, ggtext, ggfx, gganimate, showtext), Quarto
Reflection:
This project made me think harder about data than I expected. After collecting and working with my own dataset, I gained a deeper respect for the messiness of real-world data.
Code Snippet:
clean_service_data <- service_data |>
  mutate(
    help = as.logical(toupper(help)),
    working = as.logical(toupper(working))
  )
Visuals:

Service Light TableService Light Bar ChartBlinking Lights

GitHub Repo
View Live

title: Meet Rebecca!
text:
üõ§Ô∏è My Path
Before returning to school, I spent about two decades working, raising my family as well as serving 5 years in the Marine Corps Reserves. Community college helped me rediscover my interest in science and service. Now, as an Environmental Studies student at UCSB, I hope to blend research, education, and community work into a path that feels useful and rewarding.



Once Upon a Time.





Allan Hancock College.

title: About Rebecca
text:
Life Beyond the Books
When I‚Äôm not in class or out collecting data, you‚Äôll probably find me outdoors, at a local event, or hanging out with my two cats ‚Äî Chester and Leo. I like building things, learning new tools, and being part of projects that make a difference. I‚Äôm also a fan of spontaneous road trips, science memes, and really good coffee.



Chester and Leo

title: Rebecca Martinez
text:
‚ù§Ô∏è Things I Care About
I‚Äôm passionate about science that serves the community. From organizing donation drives with AGS at Hancock College to launching outreach for women veterans in Santa Barbara, I believe the best work is rooted in care and collaboration.
 

Thanks for visiting! You can explore my projects and photos pages to see what I‚Äôve been up to.

My Family.

title: About Rebecca
text:
Fieldwork Favorites



Some of my most memorable experiences have been in the field ‚Äî at places like Santa Cruz Island Reserve, Sedgwick Reserve, Rancho Marino, and even Panama. I love combining science, nature, and hands-on learning. These moments keep me grounded and curious.



Thanks for stopping by! Feel free to explore the other pages to learn more about my projects and see more photos!

title: About Rebecca
text:
Fieldwork & Research



Some of my most memorable experiences have come through hands-on work ‚Äî from the [Santa Cruz Island Reserve](projects.qmd) to Sedgwick and Rancho Marino, and even Panama. I enjoy connecting academic research with real-world ecosystems, and these projects help me stay grounded, curious, and engaged.



Thanks for stopping by! Feel free to explore the other pages to learn more about my projects and see more photos!

title: Meet Rebecca!
text:
üåø Fieldwork Adventures
I learn best by doing, especially outdoors. Fieldwork helps me connect what I study with real ecosystems and real people. I think hands-on experience is one of the best ways to inspire students and communities who might not yet see themselves in science.



Harvesting lavender to distill into oil.





With Kayla Geronimo-Anctil on Santa Cruz Island Reserve.


You can explore my projects and photos pages to see what I‚Äôve been up to.

title: Meet Rebecca!
text:
‚ù§Ô∏è Work That Matters
Giving back to the community has always been important to me. Whether mentoring, volunteering, or helping behind the scenes, I try to contribute where I can. Over the years, I‚Äôve been involved with groups like Toys for Tots, local outreach, and She Raised Her Hand.
To me, meaningful work is about showing up ‚Äî and trusting that what we offer contributes to something bigger than ourselves.



Toys for Tots Event (holding the unicorn).





Proclamation presented by the City of Santa Maria to She Raised Her Hand.


Please visit She Raised Her Hand for more information and upcoming events.
If you‚Äôd like to support seasonal giving efforts, donations can be made through Toys for Tots.

title: Projects
text:
üí° Service Light Data Project
Course: ENVS 193DS
As part of Data Science for Environmental Studies at UCSB, I explored the relationship between lighting conditions and service calls using a custom dataset of 108 observations. This included bar charts, a summary table, and a blinking lightboard animation.



Animated blinking lightboard


üîó Project Links
- üìÅ GitHub Repository
- üåê Rendered HTML Output


Tools + Skills

Tools: R (ggplot2, dplyr, gganimate), Quarto, Adobe Photoshop

Skills: Data cleaning, animation, visual storytelling, spatial reasoning



Dataset Overview

date ‚Äì Date of the call

time_interval ‚Äì Time block of the call

help ‚Äì Whether help was needed

working ‚Äì Whether the light worked

event ‚Äì Event nearby (e.g., holiday, show)

machines_active, staff_total, weekday



Artist Statement (Excerpt)
This project shows service lights as a grid, using colors to show if they were working, broken, or unknown‚Ä¶ (your full excerpt here)


Reflection
This project was eye-opening. It was my first soft attempt at collecting and using my own data. Lessons were learned. Tears were shed. I will forever think more critically about my data.

title: Projects
text:
üîç Research Projects


üíß Fog Harp Device


Affiliation: UCSB Office of Education Partnerships
Designing and field-testing fogwater monitoring devices (fog harp) to measure fog water levels.




ü¶® Skunk Population


Affiliation: UCSB-Smithsonian Scholars Program (OEP)
Undergraduate research using camera traps to monitor and quantify skunk populations on Santa Cruz Island.




üå± Soil Bioturbation by Mammals


Affiliation: UCNRS Field Science Fellowship
Mentor: Dr.¬†Iris Holzer
Investigating how small mammals like gophers and ground squirrels influence soil processes through bioturbation. Includes paired site comparisons.

Biographies



 Chester Odin



‚ÄúChester the Cheetah‚Äù Though docile and timid, Chester‚Äôs gentle and sweet nature shines through to anyone who takes the time to get to know him.  



 Leonel Vili



‚ÄúLeo the Lion‚Äù Leo is a playful polydactyl whose two great loves are meowing and hunting hair-ties.

title: Meet Rebecca!
text:
üåø Fieldwork Adventures
I‚Äôm happiest when I‚Äôm outside, learning by doing. Hands-on environmental work helps me connect what I‚Äôm learning in the classroom to real ecosystems and real people. I believe fieldwork is one of the most powerful ways to teach and inspire others ‚Äî especially students and community members who may not see themselves in science yet.



Harvesting lavender to distill into oil.





With Kayla Geronimo-Anctil on Santa Cruz Island Reserve.


You can explore my projects and photos pages to see what I‚Äôve been up to.

title: Meet Rebecca!
text:
‚ù§Ô∏è Work That Matters
Community involvement has always been a meaningful part of my life. Whether it‚Äôs through mentoring, volunteering, or helping behind the scenes, I try to contribute where I can ‚Äî not because I have all the answers, but because I believe in being part of something that gives back. Over the years, I‚Äôve stayed involved with efforts that reflect those values, like Toys for Tots, campus and local outreach, and She Raised Her Hand.
To me, meaningful work is about showing up ‚Äî and trusting that what we offer contributes to something bigger than ourselves.



Toys for Tots Event (holding the unicorn).





Proclamation presented by the City of Santa Maria to She Raised Her Hand.


Please visit She Raised Her Hand for more information and upcoming events.
If you‚Äôd like to support seasonal giving efforts, donations can be made through Toys for Tots.

title: Resources
text: Welcome to my resource page!

title: Resources
text:
Interactive 3D Anatomy
For a detailed and interactive 3D exploration of the human body, check out Zygote Body. This website allows you to zoom, rotate, and isolate specific parts of the body, making it an excellent tool for visual learning.
Explore Zygote Body

title: Resources
text:
Quizlet Flashcard Folders
Created for Dr.¬†Len Miyahara‚Äôs BIO 124 course at Allan Hancock College in 2021. Material may differ.

Skeletal System
Muscular System
Heart, Circulatory, & Respiratory Systems
Digestive, Urinary, & Reproductive Systems

title: Experience
text:
Resume
‚¨áÔ∏è Download Resume


Expand to view resume

Rebecca Martinez
Goleta, CA 93117
rebecca_martinez@ucsb.edu | martinez.rl@hotmail.com

Objective
Environmental studies undergraduate with a strong background in mentorship and peer support, dedicated to empowering academic growth through experiential learning and collaborative research. Committed to fostering curiosity, teamwork, and shared achievements to build resilient communities and drive lasting positive change.


Education
University of California, Santa Barbara (UCSB) ‚Äî Goleta, CA

B.S. in Environmental Studies | Expected 2026

Allan Hancock College ‚Äî Santa Maria, CA

A.S. in Biology, with honors | May 2024

A.A. in Biology, with honors | May 2023

A.A. in Mathematics and Science, with high honors | May 2021
Information Technology Fundamentals (IT Certificate) | May 2024



Experience

UCSB Office of Education Partnerships (OEP) ‚Äî Goleta, CA
Student Assistant | Sept 2024 ‚Äì Present

Contribute to data collection, field site maintenance, and equipment repair for Island Spotted Skunk & Fog Harp projects on Santa Cruz Island.

Assist with updating field protocols and project documentation to support ongoing research.

Collaborate with a team to enhance project logistics and operational efficiency.



Smithsonian Office of the Chief Information Officer (OCIO) ‚Äî Remote
Data Science Lab Intern | May 2024 ‚Äì August 2024

Led weekly RStudio sessions, adapting teaching methods to improve learning outcomes.

Mentored peers in applying research methodologies to real-world datasets.

Developed and refined resources to enhance data science comprehension.



Allan Hancock College ‚Äî Santa Maria, CA
Teaching Assistant | Jan 2024 ‚Äì May 2024

Managed lab operations, including setup, compliance, and student support.

Provided and created supplemental study materials to enhance student learning.

Lead Tutor | Aug 2020 ‚Äì May 2024

Coordinated tutor schedules and assisted in campus-wide training initiatives.

Developed and delivered workshops to improve study skills and academic performance.

Collaborated with campus centers to enhance tutoring services and resources.

Peer Tutor | Aug 2019 ‚Äì May 2024

Provided academic support in STEM subjects through one-on-one and group sessions.

Assisted students in developing effective study and time management strategies.

Served as an embedded tutor in multiple science courses.



Chumash Casino Resort ‚Äî Santa Ynez, CA
Slot Attendant | Jan 2012 - May 2025

Troubleshoot and resolve slot machine issues, address disputes promptly and tactfully to ensure a seamless guest experience.

Ensure machines and equipment are functioning properly, maintaining the integrity of the gaming environment and upholding tribal gaming compliance.

Floor Operations Supervisor | June 2007 - Jan 2012

Supervised daily operations for the slot and beverage departments, overseeing up to 75 team members per shift.

Developed staff schedules and ensured operational efficiency during peak times.

Addressed guest concerns to maintain a positive and safe environment.

Security Officer | June 2006 - June 2007

Patrolled casino floor, staffed guard posts, and provided secure escorts.

Handled chip drops and safeguarded money movements across the property.




Skills

Data analysis & visualization (RStudio)

Field research & data collection

Leadership & mentoring

Communication & presentation

Microsoft Office Suite

Problem-solving & adaptability

Time management

Team collaboration



References
Available upon request.
